The '''humanitarian response to the [[2010 Haiti earthquake]]''' included national governments, charitable and for-profit organizations from around the world which began coordinating [[humanitarian aid]] designed to help the Haitian people. Some countries arranged to send relief and rescue workers and humanitarian supplies directly to the earthquake damage zones, while others sought to organize national fund raising to provide monetary support for the nonprofit groups working directly in Haiti. [[OCHA]] and [[ReliefWeb]] are coordinating and tracking this on a daily basis.<ref>[http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/datablog/2010/jan/14/haiti-quake-aid-pledges-country-donations ], [[The Guardian]], 14 January 2010.</ref> As of March 21, 2010, [[Reliefweb]] have reported a total relief funding of $2.5 billion given and a further $1.3 billion pledged.<ref>Reliefweb: Haiti Earthquakes funding tracker http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/fts.nsf/doc105?OpenForm&rc=2&emid=EQ-2010-000009-HTI</ref>
A number of countries sent large contingents of disaster relief, medical staff, technicians for reconstruction and security personnel. Notably, the governments of the [[United States]], [[Israel]] ,the [[Dominican Republic]], [[Canada]], [[Brazil]], [[Italy]] and [[Cuba]]<ref>Tom Fawthrop. [http://english.aljazeera.net/focus/2010/01/201013195514870782.html Cuba's Aid Ignored By The Media?], AlJazeera.net, February 16, 2010. Retrieved July 14, 2010.</ref> sent over 1,000 military and disaster relief personnel each, with the United States being by far the largest single contributor to the relief efforts. The international community also committed numerous major assets such as field hospitals, naval vessels, a hospital ship, aircraft carriers, transport aircraft and emergency facilities soon after the extent of the disaster became apparent.
Progress in responding to the almost unprecedented scale of disaster was hampered by numerous factors, including major loss of life, multiple large aftershocks, devastated civil infrastructures, collapsed buildings blocking streets, the lack of electricity for gasoline station pumps, plus the loss of the capitol's seaport and air traffic control facilities. Additionally, the significant damage to the Haitian government ministries, all of which suffered varying degrees of destruction and personnel deaths, further impeded coordination of the disaster response.
In April 2010, the Haiti government asked that massive food distribution in the Petionville camp cease in order to allow the normal economy to resume.<ref>
{{Cite news | first = Mary | last = St. Pierre | title = Rebuilding Haiti one small step at a time | url = http://thefloridacatholic.org/iv/view/item/222| work= | publisher = Florida Catholic | location = Orlando, Florida | pages = A1 | date = April 23-May 6, 2010 | id = | accessdate=}}</ref>
== Appeals for aid ==
Appeals for international aid were issued, including by [[Raymond Joseph]], Haiti's [[ambassador]] to the United States and his nephew, singer [[Wyclef Jean]],<ref>[http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/americas/01/12/haiti.aid/ "Appeals for aid after quake strikes Haiti"]. CNN. 13 January 2010. Retrieved 13 January 2010.</ref> also a "roving ambassador" for Haiti.<ref>
{{cite news| url = http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/16459449/| title = Wyclef Jean to be Haitiâs roving ambassador| last = Reuters|date=3 January 2007| publisher = [[MSNBC]]| accessdate = 13 January 2010}}
</ref> The American Red Cross quickly announced that it had run out of supplies in Haiti and appealed for public donations.<ref>
{{cite web|last=Press |first=Associated |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/politics/wire/sns-ap-us-us-haiti-red-cross,0,3443905.story |title=American Red Cross says it has run out of medical supplies in Haiti |publisher=latimes.com |date= |accessdate=2010-01-15}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}
</ref> British charities soon launched a massive fundraising effort.<ref>
{{cite web|url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/uk-world-news/2010/01/13/british-charities-launch-huge-appeal-to-help-homeless-and-injured-after-haiti-earthquake-86908-21964861/ |title=British charities launch huge appeal to help homeless and injured after Haiti earthquake |publisher=The Daily Record |date=2010-01-10 |accessdate=2010-01-15}}
</ref> Ireland, which as a country has a history of helping Haitians build houses and has notable connections to Haiti through charities [[Concern Worldwide|Concern]] and [[GOAL (charity)|GOAL]], telecommunications operator [[Denis O'Brien]] and broadcaster [[George Hook]],<ref>[http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/property/2009/0115/1231738223248.html ''The Irish Times''], "Irish charity to build houses in Haiti", Thursday, January 15, 2009</ref><ref>Niamh Hennessy, [http://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/hook-urges-volunteers-to-get-building-in-haiti-109542.html ''Irish Examiner''], "Hook urges volunteers to get building in Haiti", Wednesday, January 13, 2010</ref><ref>[http://www.irishcentral.com/story/news/periscope/irish-connections-run-very-deep-to-haiti-81292117.html Irish Central] "Irish connections run very deep to Haiti", Tuesday, January 12, 2010 at 11:58 PM</ref> immediately switched all its charitable efforts to helping those affected by the quake.<ref>Jamie Smyth, [http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/world/2010/0115/1224262377793.html ''The Irish Times''], "Aid agencies ask public for donations to help injured and homeless", Friday, January 15, 2010</ref>
== Response by national governments ==
[[File:supplydeliver.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Rescue supplies delivered to Haiti from US Navy ships]] {{Main|Humanitarian response by national governments to the 2010 Haiti earthquake}}
== Response by intergovernmental organizations == === Commonwealth realms === Queen [[Elizabeth II]], monarch of each of the [[Commonwealth realm]]s, made a donation to the relief effort and issued a personal message of condolence to the President of Haiti.<ref>{{Citation| last=Press Association| title=Brown urges Haiti quake donations| newspaper=The Guardian| date=14 January 2010| url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/feedarticle/8899053| accessdate=15 January 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.royal.gov.uk/LatestNewsandDiary/Overview.aspx| last=Royal Household| title=Latest News and Diary > The Queen's message to The President of Haiti| publisher=Queen's Printer| accessdate=15 January 2010}}</ref>
=== EU === In early January 2010 the [[EU]] released â¬3 m in emergency funding.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/0113/haiti.html |title=RTÃ News: Charities appeal for Haiti earthquake aid |publisher=Rte.ie |date= |accessdate=2010-01-13}}</ref>
The [[European Council]] and its member nations later announced more than â¬429 million ({{US$|600,000,000}}) in emergency humanitarian aid, rehabilitation aid and medium-to long-term reconstruction aid.<ref>{{cite web|author=Sapa-AFP |url=http://www.businessday.co.za/articles/Content.aspx?id=91461 |title=EU earmarks over â¬420 million for Haiti |publisher=Businessday.co.za |date=2010-01-18 |accessdate=2010-01-23}}</ref> The aid was to be provided as detailed: ;Humanitarian Assistance The EU pledged â¬122 million in humanitarian assistance: Emergency relief aid package: â¬30 million (incl. a â¬3 million ECHO fast-track decision). Commission funds were to be distributed via UN agencies, international NGOs and the Red Cross. â¬92 million from member countries. ;Support for Early Recovery and Reinforcing State Capacity. The European Commission pledged to provide â¬100 million for short term recovery and rehabilitation. ;Reconstruction and Rehabilitation. The European Commission pledged to provide â¬200 million from the 10th and 9th EDF funds for Haiti. They would be in addition to bilateral contributions from EU Member States' budgets. <ref>{{cite news|url=http://europa.eu/rapid/pressReleasesAction.do?reference=MEMO/10/9&format=HTML&aged=0&language=EN&guiLanguage=en |Factsheet on Haiti earthquake|source=EU Commission|date=20 January 2010}}</ref>
The European Union thus pledged at least â¬429 million to Haiti in both emergency and humanitarian aid to help the medium and long term work of rebuilding the country devastated by the earthquake. In addition, the 27 countries decided to send some 150 troops from the European Gendarmerie to ensure that humanitarian aid would reach the people affected by the earthquake.
The financial contribution of the EU as a whole totaled â¬429 million, broken down as: *â¬92 million coming from contributions made by Member States, *â¬30 million from the European Commission itself, *â¬107 million from existing EU funds that were being redirected to Haiti, and another *â¬200 million shuffled for the medium and long term rehabilitation.<ref>
{{cite web|url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20100118/ap_on_re_eu/eu_eu_haiti |title=EU nations pledge $575 million for Haiti aid - Yahoo! News |publisher=News.yahoo.com |date= |accessdate=2010-01-23}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
=== Organization of American States === The [[Organization of American States]] donated {{US$|100 000}}.<ref>{{cite news|date=2010-01-15 |agency=Associated Press |url=http://www.etaiwannews.com/etn/news_content.php?id=1156873&lang=eng_news |title=OAS donates $100,000 in aid to Haiti |publisher=Etaiwannews.com |accessdate=2010-01-23}}</ref>
=== Union of South American Nations === The [[Union of South American Nations]] pledged {{US$|300 000 000}} to help rebuild Haiti on long terms. A meeting was held in Quito in order to discuss how it would be utilized.<ref>http://english.cctv.com/program/worldwidewatch/20100210/108198.shtml</ref>
=== United Nations === As the extent of the catastrophe unfolded, United Nations Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon commented: "There is no doubt that we are facing a major humanitarian emergency and that a major relief effort will be required". The U.N. mobilized an emergency response team to help coordinate humanitarian relief efforts.<ref>[http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/americas/01/13/haiti.quake.world.reaction/index.html U.N. chief calls on world to help crisis-hit Haiti].</ref> * The [[United Nations Security Council|Security Council]] authorised an increase of 3,500 troops and police of the [[United Nations Stabilization Mission in Haiti]] in [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1908|Resolution 1908]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=33516&Cr=haiti&Cr1=|title=Security Council authorizes 3,500 more UN peacekeepers for Haiti|date=19 January 2010|publisher=UN News Centre}}</ref> * The [[World Bank]] provided extra funding of $100 million to support recovery and reconstruction in Haiti.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://web.worldbank.org/WBSITE/EXTERNAL/NEWS/0,,contentMDK:22440632~pagePK:64257043~piPK:437376~theSitePK:4607,00.html |title=World Bank to Provide an Additional $100 Million to Haiti, Following Earthquake |publisher=Web.worldbank.org |date= |accessdate=2010-01-13}}</ref> * [[UNICEF]] made an emergency appeal for assistance to aid the victims.<ref name="UNICEF">[http://www.unicef.org.uk/emergency/emergency_detail.asp?emergency=63 "Haiti Earthquake Children's Appeal"]. Retrieved 13 January 2010.</ref> * The [[World Health Organization]] sent a "12-member team of health and logistics experts."<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/releases/2010/haiti_earthquake_20100113/en/index.html |title=WHO response in Haiti |accessdate=2010-01-14}}</ref> * The [[World Food Program]] provided over 200 staff members on the ground, with their rapid-response team supporting the entire humanitarian effort."<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.wfp.org/stories/haiti-wfp-bring-food-devastating-quake |title=WFP response in Haiti |accessdate=2010-01-16}}</ref> * The [[International Atomic Energy Agency]] sent eight mobile medical X-ray machines to Haiti.<ref>Earth Times, [http://www.earthtimes.org/articles/show/306587,iaea-ships-x-ray-units-to-haiti.html "IAEA ships X-ray units to Haiti"], ''29 January 2010'' (accessed 29 January 2010)</ref> * The Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs established a coordination office in Haiti to coordinate the international relief effort in support of the Government of Haiti.<ref>OCHA, [http://ochaonline.un.org/OCHAHome/WhereWeWork/Haiti/HaitiOCHAsResponse/tabid/6422/language/en-US/Default.aspx "OCHA's Response - Fact Sheet"], ''29 January 2010'' (accessed 9 February 2010)</ref>
== Response by non-governmental organizations == {{Main|Humanitarian response by non-governmental organizations to the 2010 Haiti earthquake}}
Many [[non-governmental organization]]s, including international, religious and regionally-based NGOs, immediately pledged support in the aftermath of the 2010 Haiti earthquake. NGOs contributed significantly to both on-the-ground rescue efforts and external solicitation of aid for those rescue efforts.
